choices.text: Degeneration of the dorsal and lateral spinal columns

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She was also diagnosed with active pulmonary tuberculosis 4 months ago. She completed 2 months of intensive antituberculosis therapy with 4 drugs and now is on isoniazid and rifampin alone. The patient feels well overall but does have tingling and numbness of the bilateral hands and feet that started a few weeks ago; she has no cough, fever, chills, or night sweats. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 80/min. Lung auscultation reveals fine crackles in the left upper lung field. Heart sounds are normal and regular. Neurologic examination shows normal motor strength but decreased touch and pain sensation in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Skin examination shows no abnormalities. Hemoglobin A1C level is 7.4%. Chest x-ray reveals fibrotic changes in the left upper lung. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isoniazid is chemically similar to pyridoxine (vitamin B6.). Because of this similarity, isoniazid can compete with vitamin B6, in the synthesis of multiple neurotransmitters (including GABA), resulting in defective end products. Isoniazid also increases the urinary excretion of pyridoxine, and a frank deficiency of this vitamin can eventually develop.
  • Vitamin B6, deficiency most commonly occurs in patients treated with isoniazid who are elderly, alcoholics, or who have other comorbidities (eg, kidney or liver dysfunction, diabetes mellitus).
  • When isoniazid neuropathy occurs, it usually clinically manifests as peripheral neuropathy. To prevent these adverse effects, supplemental vitamin B6 is typically prescribed in conjunction with isoniazid.
  • Other potential adverse effect of isoniazid:

Hepatotoxicity, P-450 Inhibition, Drug induced SLE, Anion Gap metabolic acidosis

To Remember: INH(Isoniazid) Injures Neurons and Hepatocytes

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Degeneration of the dorsal and lateral spinal columns (Option A): This is characteristic of vitamin B12 deficiency, which typically presents with loss of vibration and position sense, spasticity, and sometimes ataxia. This patient has decreased touch and pain sensation, not primarily proprioceptive loss, and there is no macrocytic anemia.

Inflammatory demyelination of axons (Option B): This occurs in conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome, which presents with ascending weakness, areflexia, and sometimes sensory disturbances, often following infection. This patient has normal motor strength and chronic sensory symptoms, making acute demyelination unlikely.

Loss of motor neurons (Option D): Seen in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, characterized by progressive weakness, muscle wasting, fasciculations, and minimal sensory deficits. The patient's symptoms are purely sensory, ruling this out.

choices.text: Decrease carbohydrate polymerization of mycobacterium cell wall

questions.text: Patient on anti-tubercular drugs comes to opd with complain of Red urine. He has had no pain or burning on urination. He has infiltrative pulmonary tuberculosis (diagnosed recently). He takes anti M. Tuberculosis drugs. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Orange urine (which is nonhazardous), Minor hepatotoxicity and drug interaction (increase cytochrome P-450) are side effects of Rifampin. Mechanism of action of rifampin is inhibiting DNA-Dependent RNA polymerase.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Decrease synthesis of mycolic acid (Option B): This describes the mechanism of isoniazid, which inhibits mycolic acid synthesis in the mycobacterial cell wall. Its main side effects include peripheral neuropathy and hepatotoxicity, not red/orange urine.

Decrease carbohydrate polymerization of mycobacterium cell wall (Option C): This is the mechanism of ethambutol, which inhibits arabinosyl transferase, thereby disrupting cell wall carbohydrate polymerization. Main side effect: optic neuritis (red-green color blindness), not discolored urine.

Interferes with 30S component of ribosome (Option D): This is the mechanism of streptomycin, which interferes with protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit. Side effects: ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, but not red urine.

choices.text: Replace drug with second line anti tubercular drugs

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to clinic complaining of severe shortness of breath, cough, and hemoptysis. A chest radiograph reveals right upper lobe fibrosis and her sputum is positive for acid-fast bacilli. A diagnosis of active pulmonary tuberculosis is made and she is begun on a regimen of isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. She presents for a follow-up visit one month later and says that her symptoms have improved and she feels "much better." Her sputum is now negative for acid-fast bacilli. Laboratory evaluation returns with the following:
Liver studies
Albumin 4.8 g/dL
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 42 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT) 75 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGPT) 97 U/L
What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isoniazid is a bactericidal antibiotic that is particularly effective against replicating Mycobacterium tuberculosis when used in conjunction with other agents such as rifampin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide.
  • Isoniazid (INH) is not without adverse effects, however, and has been associated with severe INH hepatitis and a much milder hepatotoxicity. Isoniazid hepatitis presents with clinical manifestations that are similar to those seen with viral hepatitis.
  • The risk of developing this more ominous form of hepatotoxicity is estimated to be 2.6% for those who drink alcohol daily, already have liver disease, or are age 50 years and older.
  • If signs and symptoms of INH hepatitis are observed, the drug should be discontinued immediately.
  • In contrast, it is estimated that 10-20% of patients taking INH will experience mild, subclinical hepatic injury demonstrated only by minor elevations in serum aminotransferases (typically < 10011.1/L).
  • The prognosis is excellent in these patients and the condition is self-limited, allowing for INH therapy to be maintained with close follow-up.
  • Because the patient in this question is relatively young and otherwise asymptomatic, she can continue taking INH as long as her liver function tests are regularly monitored and remain only mildly elevated.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Terminate current treatment (Option A):

Stopping therapy would risk treatment failure and resistance. Mild asymptomatic transaminitis (<3x ULN) with normal bilirubin does not require stopping drugs.

Replace drug with second-line anti-tubercular drugs (Option C):

Second-line drugs are considered only when there is significant hepatotoxicity (ALT/AST >5x ULN if asymptomatic, >3x ULN with symptoms, or if bilirubin is elevated). That's not the case here.

Liver biopsy (Option D):

Indicated for diagnosis of unclear liver disease or persistent, unexplained LFT abnormalities, not for mild, expected enzyme elevation from anti-TB drugs.

choices.text: Altered structure of enzymes involved in bacterial DNA winding-unwinding
Altered structure of enzymes involved in bacterial RNA synthesis
Altered structure of bacterial ribosomal proteins

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with HIV is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and started on a 4-drug combination therapy. On a follow-up visit 3 weeks later, he reports red urine and red staining of his contact lenses. A drug susceptibility test of his sputum isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis shows resistance to several antimycobacterial agents. Which of the following best explains the bacterial resistance to the drug responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient with HIV has active pulmonary tuberculosis, typically treated with a 4-drug combination of a rifamycin (eg, rifampin, rifabutin), isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE therapy).
  • The Rifamycins commonly cause harmless red-orange discoloration of body fluids (urine, sweat, saliva, tears), which explains this patient's symptoms. They inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, thereby preventing transcription and leading to a deficiency of proteins necessary for mycobacterial survival.
  • Structural alteration of this DNA-dependent RNA polymerase induces bacterial resistance. Unlike isoniazid, rifamycins are not specific to mycobacteria.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Altered Structure of enzymes involved in bacterial DNA Winding (Option A):
Refers to resistance against fluoroquinolones (DNA gyrase/topoisomerase II inhibitors). Not related to rifampin.

Altered Ribosomal Proteins (Option C):
This mechanism is seen with aminoglycosides, macrolides, and tetracyclines. Rifampin does not act on ribosomes.

Decreased Catalase-Peroxidase Activity (Option D):
This explains resistance to isoniazid (INH), since the drug needs catalase-peroxidase for activation. Not related to rifampin.

questions.text: A 31-year-old Woman comes to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fever, night sweats, and productive cough. He has also had a 4-kg weight loss. Chest-x ray reveals a cavitary lesion on the right. Sputum culture is obtained. When exposed to drug A, isolates of the pathogen growing in culture quickly become less resistant to decoloration with an acid-alcohol agent and stop proliferating. Which of the following is drug A most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isoniazid is an antimicrobial agent that is active only against mycobacteria. Its specificity is derived from its inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Mycolic acids form long branched-chain fatty acids in the outer portion of the mycobacterial peptidoglycan cell wall; they are essential for proper cell wall structure and virulence factor synthesis (eg, sulfatides, wax D, cord factor). If mycobacteria are unable to synthesize mycolic acids, they cannot create proper cell walls or divide to form new cells.
  • Mycolic acids in the cell wall cause mycobacteria to be acid-fast as they retain the carbolfuchsin dye and resist decoloration by an acid-alcohol decolorizing agent.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Ciprofloxacin (Option A):

A fluoroquinolone that inhibits DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II), preventing bacterial DNA replication. It is not specific to Mycobacterium tuberculosis and does not cause increased acid-fast sensitivity.

Rifampin (Option B):

Inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, blocking transcription. While effective against M. tuberculosis and causing red body fluids, it does not directly interfere with mycolic acid synthesis, which explains the change in acid-fastness.

Streptomycin (Option D):

An aminoglycoside that binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit, inhibiting protein synthesis. It is used as a second-line TB drug but does not affect acid-fast cell wall properties.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis 2 months back returns to the office reporting blurring of vision. The patient is on combination therapy with isoniazid, ethambutol, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and pyridoxine. Examination shows bilateral central scotomas. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's visual symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pulmonary TB is treated with a 4-drug regimen, sometimes referred to as RIPE: rifampin, isoniazid (INH), pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.
  • The most notable side effect of ethambutol is optic neuropathy, which clinically manifests as decreased visual acuity, central scotoma, or color blindness. It may be reversible with discontinuation of the drug.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Isoniazid (Option B):

Can cause peripheral neuropathy (due to pyridoxine deficiency) and drug-induced hepatitis, but it does not typically cause optic neuritis or central vision loss.

Pyrazinamide (Option C):

Associated with hyperuricemia (gouty arthritis) and hepatotoxicity, but visual disturbances are not a recognized side effect.

Rifampin (Option D):

Causes red-orange discoloration of body fluids and hepatotoxicity. It does not cause optic neuropathy.

questions.text:
A patient presented with a few hypoesthetic, hairless skin plaques. Diagnosis of leprosy confirmed with tissue biopsy. What is the mechanism of action of drugs used to treat this condition?
i) Inhibit dihydropteroate synthase
ii) Inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase
iii) binding preferentially to mycobacterial DNA and inhibiting replication and growth
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patient is having presentation of Tuberculoid leprosy. Treatment of tuberculoid leprosy is dapsone and rifampin. Mechanism of action of dapsone and rifampin are inhibit dihydropteroate synthase and Inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase respectively.
    • Lepromatous-presents diffusely over the skin, with leonine (lion-like) facies, and is communicable (high bacterial load); characterized by low cell-mediated immunity with a humoral Th2 response.
    • Tuberculoid-limited to a few hypo esthetic, hairless skin plaques; characterized by high cell mediated immunity with a largely Th1-type immune response and low bacterial load.
    • Treatment: dapsone and rifampin for tuberculoid form; clofazimine is added for lepromatous form.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Option A (i):

Refers only to dapsone, which inhibits dihydropteroate synthase (folate pathway inhibitor, similar to sulfonamides). While correct, this ignores the role of rifampin in standard multidrug therapy.

Option C (i, ii, iii):

Includes clofazimine (iii), which binds to mycobacterial DNA. However, clofazimine is used mainly in multibacillary leprosy or resistant cases, not always part of standard first-line multidrug therapy for all patients.

Option D (i, iii):

Excludes rifampin's mechanism (ii). Since rifampin is a cornerstone of therapy, this is incomplete.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to fever, anorexia, and nausea. Several weeks ago, on routine testing, the patient was found to have a positive purified protein derivative test. He had no respiratory symptoms, and a chest x-ray was unremarkable. A month ago, he started isoniazid therapy with pyridoxine supplementation. Currently, temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 °F). On physical examination, there is mild abdominal discomfort. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient with latent tuberculosis infection (positive tuberculin skin test, no symptoms, unremarkable chest x-ray) was started on isoniazid (INH) therapy and now has fever, anorexia, and nausea.
  • INH is directly hepatotoxic. In 10% - 20% of patients, it causes acute, mild hepatic dysfunction, characterized by transient increases in serum aminotransferases (AST/SGOT, ALT/SGPT). This adverse effect usually occurs during the first 4-6 months of treatment, and, in most cases, liver function tests return to baseline with continued INH therapy.
  • In rare instances (<1%), frank hepatitis (similar to viral hepatitis with fever, anorexia, nausea, jaundice) can occur (as seen in this patient) and sometimes evolves into a severe form with progressive liver dysfunction and death.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Factitious disorder (Option A):

This is a psychiatric condition in which patients deliberately produce or feign symptoms to assume the sick role. It does not explain the temporal relationship between starting isoniazid and the onset of fever, nausea, anorexia, and abdominal discomfort.

Gastric mucosal damage (Option B):

This would be more typical of NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin, indomethacin) or alcohol use, leading to epigastric pain and possible bleeding. Isoniazid toxicity is not primarily gastric.

Peripheral nerve damage (Option D):

Isoniazid does cause peripheral neuropathy due to pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency. However, this patient is already on pyridoxine supplementation, and his presentation (fever, anorexia, abdominal discomfort) is much more consistent with hepatic injury than neuropathy.

questions.text: Typical adult dose of rifampin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

300 mg/day (Option A):

This is too low for standard adult therapy. Such a dose would be subtherapeutic, risking treatment failure and resistance.

25 mg/kg/day (Option B):

This is much higher than recommended and would increase the risk of hepatotoxicity and other adverse effects.

15 mg/kg/day (Option C):

This corresponds more closely to pediatric dosing or weight-based adjustments in children, not typical adult fixed dosing.

choices.text: Decrease carbohydrate polymerization of mycobacterium cell

questions.text: Which of the following is not mechanism of action of first line agent of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Interferes with 30s component of ribosome is mechanism of action of Streptomycin , Which is second line drug for tuberculosis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (Option A):

This is the mechanism of rifampin, a first-line TB drug.

Decrease synthesis of mycolic acids (Option B):

This is the mechanism of isoniazid, another first-line drug.

Decrease carbohydrate polymerization of mycobacterial cell wall (Option D):

This is the mechanism of ethambutol, which inhibits arabinosyl transferase.

questions.text: Drug use in initial treatment of mycobacterium Avium?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Initial regimen for mycobacterium avium:
  • At least two-antimycobacterial drugs; preferred agents include: Macrolide: clarithromycin (first-line) OR azithromycin AND ethambutol

choices.text: A high risk of mortality (e.g., CD4 count < 50)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of using rifabutin/fluroquinolones in patient having mycobacterium avium infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Initial regimen for mycobacterium avium:
    • At least two-antimycobacterial drugs; preferred agents include:
  • Macrolide: clarithromycin (first-line) ORazithromycin AND ethambutol
  • Optional third and fourth drugs[1]
  • Consider in patients with any of the following:
    • A high risk of mortality (e.g., CD4 count< 50)
    • Drug resistance
    • High mycobacterialload
    • Inadequate response to ART
  • Agents (any of the following):
    • Rifabutin
    • Fluoroquinolone: levofloxacin or moxifloxacin
    • Injectable agent: amikacin or streptomycin

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

High risk of mortality (Option A):

Rifabutin or fluoroquinolones are indicated in patients with advanced immunosuppression (CD4 < 50) to reduce the risk of severe MAC disease.

Drug resistance (Option B):

These drugs are considered when there is resistance to first-line MAC therapy, making them valid indications.

Inadequate response to ART (Option C):

Rifabutin or fluoroquinolones may be added if ART alone does not control MAC infection.

choices.text: Inhibit prokaryotic enzymes topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase)
Inhibit protein synthesis by binding to 50S subunit

questions.text: 57-year-old female having tuberculosis comes to the clinic with complain of tinnitus, vertigo. She was on second line drug of anti-tuberculosis because of resistant to some of the first line drug. which of the following is mechanism of action of drug causing patients symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Below are second line drugs use in treatment of tuberculosis.
  • Tinnitus, vertigo, ataxia, nephrotoxicity are side effect of streptomycin.
  • Mechanism of action of streptomycin: Interferes with 30S component of ribosome

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Topoisomerase II inhibition (Option B):

Refers to fluoroquinolones, which inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase. These do not typically cause ototoxicity (tinnitus, vertigo).

50S subunit binding (Option C):

Refers to macrolides or chloramphenicol, which inhibit protein synthesis at the 50S subunit. These are not typically associated with vestibular toxicity.

None of the above (Option D):

This is incorrect because the patient's symptoms are explained by the known mechanism of aminoglycosides (second-line TB drugs like streptomycin, amikacin, kanamycin).

questions.text: Rifampicin increase elimination of all of the following drugs except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rifampin strongly induces most cytochrome P450 isoforms (CYP1A2, 2C9, 2C19, 2D6, and 3A4), which increases the elimination of numerous other drugs including methadone, anticoagulants, cyclosporine, some anticonvulsants, protease inhibitors, some nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors or integrase strand transfer inhibitors, contraceptives, and a host of others.

Coadministration of rifampin results in significantly lower serum levels of these drugs.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Methadone (Option A):

Rifampicin induces hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes, increasing the metabolism of methadone and potentially leading to withdrawal symptoms.

Cyclosporine (Option B):

Rifampicin induces CYP3A4, reducing cyclosporine plasma concentrations and risking transplant rejection if not adjusted.

Anticoagulants (Option C):

Rifampicin accelerates metabolism of warfarin via CYP induction, decreasing its anticoagulant effect.

questions.text: If a protease inhibitor-based antiretroviral regimen is used to treat his HIV, Then which of the following anti-tuberculosis drug should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • If a protease inhibitor-based antiretroviral regimen is used to treat his HIV, rifabutin should replace rifampin because of the serious drug interactions between rifampin and protease inhibitors.
  • If dolutegravir is chosen, it must be administered twice daily due to the interaction with rifampin; alternatively, rifabutin can be used in place of rifampin, and dolutegravir can be dosed once daily.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Isoniazid (Option B):

Safe to use with protease inhibitors; no significant CYP450 interaction.

Ethambutol (Option C):

Safe to use; it is primarily renally excreted and does not interact significantly with protease inhibitors.

Rifabutin (Option D):

Can be used as an alternative to rifampin in patients on protease inhibitors; dose adjustment may be required, but it does not cause the severe drug-drug interactions seen with rifampin.

questions.text: Which of the following first line anti-tubercular drug is not having only hepatic clearance and dose need to be reduced in patient with renal failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rifampin, Isoniazid and Pyrazinamide are cleared by only liver. Ethambutol has mixed clearance (liver and renal) and dose should be reduced in patient with renal failure.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rifampin (Option A):

Almost entirely hepatically metabolized, minimal renal excretion. Dose adjustment is not required in renal failure.

Isoniazid (Option B):

Primarily hepatically metabolized via acetylation. Dose adjustment in renal failure is generally not necessary.

Pyrazinamide (Option D):

Mainly hepatically metabolized, although metabolites are renally excreted. In mild-to-moderate renal failure, dose adjustment is usually not required unless severe impairment exists.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tuberculosis drug is not bactericidal drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bactericidal drugs: A substance that directly kills bacteria.
  • Bacteriostatic drugs: A substance that stops bacteria from reproducing (does not directly kill bacteria).
  • Rifampin, Isoniazid and Streptomycin are bactericidal drugs. Where as ethambutol and Pyrazinamide are bacteriostatic drugs.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rifampin (Option A):

Bactericidal; inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, leading to rapid killing of actively dividing mycobacteria.

Isoniazid (Option B):

Bactericidal against rapidly dividing mycobacteria; inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.

Streptomycin (Option D):

Bactericidal; aminoglycoside that binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit, disrupting protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bactericidal drugs: A substance that directly kills bacteria.
  • Bacteriostatic drugs: A substance that stops bacteria from reproducing (does not directly kill bacteria).
  • Rifampin, Isoniazid and Streptomycin are bactericidal drugs. Where as ethambutol and Pyrazinamide are bacteriostatic drugs.

The following antituberculosis drugs are contraindicated in pregnant women:

  • Streptomycin
  • Kanamycin
  • Amikacin
  • Capreomycin
  • Fluoroquinolones

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rifampin (Option A):

Can be used in pregnancy if indicated. May slightly increase the risk of hemorrhagic disorders in the newborn due to vitamin K depletion, but not an absolute contraindication.

Isoniazid (Option B):

Safe in pregnancy; pyridoxine supplementation is recommended to prevent neuropathy.

Ethambutol (Option C):

Considered safe in pregnancy, with no significant teratogenicity reported.

questions.text: Isoniazid is inducer of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Isoniazid:

  • Both inducer and inhibitor.
  • Potent inhibitor of CYP2C19, CYP3A.
  • Weak inhibitor of CYP2D6.
  • Inducer of CYP2E1
  • Other drugs metabolised by CYP2E1 are Paracetamol and Ethanol.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

CYP2D1 (Option A):

This isoenzyme is primarily involved in metabolism of drugs like beta-blockers and antidepressants; isoniazid does not significantly induce it.

CYP2C19 (Option C):

Metabolizes proton pump inhibitors and some antiepileptics; isoniazid does not induce this enzyme.

CYP2D6 (Option D):

Metabolizes opioids, antidepressants, and beta-blockers; isoniazid is not an inducer of CYP2D6.

questions.text: Daily Dose of pyrazinamide in treatment of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

5 mg/kg (Option A):

Too low; would be subtherapeutic, risking treatment failure and resistance.

10 mg/kg (Option B):

Insufficient for effective bactericidal activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

15 mg/kg (Option C):

ed daily dose, not optimal for standard treatment regimens.

questions.text: Which of the following Anti-Tubercular Drug causing Neuro-Psychiatric Side effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cycloserine is associated with Neuro-Psychiatric Side effect.

Adverse effect of 2nd line Anti-Tubercular Drug:

  • Thioacetazone (tuberculostatic drug): Hepatitis, bone marrow suppression and Steven Johnson syndrome.
  • Para amino salicylic acid (PAS) can cause kidney, liver and thyroid dysfunction.
  • Ethionamide can cause hepatitis, optic neuritis and hypothyroidism.
  • Cycloserine can cause neuropsychiatric adverse effects.
  • Kanamycin, Amikacin and Capreomycin can cause ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.
  • Rifabutin commonly causes gastrointestinal adverse effects. Rarely, it can cause anterior uveitis, clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, diffuse polymyalgia syndrome, yellow skin discoloration (Pseudo-jaundice) and pancytopenia.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Para-aminosalicylic acid (PAS) (Option B):

Mainly causes gastrointestinal upset (nausea, diarrhea) and hypersensitivity reactions, not neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Thioacetazone (Option C):

Known for cutaneous reactions and hepatotoxicity, but neuropsychiatric side effects are rare.

Ethionamide (Option D):

Can cause hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal upset, and peripheral neuropathy, but psychiatric manifestations are uncommon.

choices.text: Resistance to any one of H, Z and E
Resistance to any two or all 3 of H, Z and E
Resistance to H and R + any of FQ + any of injections

questions.text: MDR-TB defined as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

(H- ISONIAZID, R- RIFAMPIN, Z- PYRAZINAMIDE, E- ETHAMBUTOL, FQ- FLUROQUINOLONES)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Resistance to any one of H, Z, and E (Option A):

This describes mono-resistance, not multidrug resistance.

Resistance to any two or all three of H, Z, and E (Option B):

Partial resistance may include poly-resistance, but MDR-TB specifically requires isoniazid and rifampin resistance.

Resistance to H and R + any of FQ + any of injections (Option D):

This defines XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB), which is beyond MDR-TB.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is ineffective in treatment of type 2 lepra reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All of the drug mentioned in options are effective in treatment of type 2 lepra reaction.

[ TT- Tuberculoid Leprosy, LL- Lepromatous Leprosy, Borderline Forms (BT, BB, BL) are between the two ends of the spectrum (TT and LL).]

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Corticosteroid (Option A):

Effective in suppressing inflammation and pain in type 2 lepra reactions.

Clofazimine (Option B):

Has anti-inflammatory properties; used in prolonged therapy to prevent recurrent ENL episodes.

Thalidomide (Option C):

Highly effective in type 2 lepra reactions, particularly in severe or corticosteroid-resistant cases.

questions.text: Which of the following best drug for slowly multiplying bacteria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Isoniazid (Option A):

Highly bactericidal against rapidly dividing mycobacteria, but less effective against dormant or slowly replicating bacteria.

Rifampicin (Option B):

Bactericidal against both rapidly and semi-dormant bacteria, but less selective for acidic environmentscompared to pyrazinamide.

Ethambutol (Option D):

Bacteriostatic, mainly prevents cell wall synthesis, not particularly active against slowly multiplying or dormant bacilli.

questions.text: Which of the following Anti-Tubercular Drug have maximum CSF Penetration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Isoniazid has maximum CSF penetration. And Streptomycin has minimum CSF penetration.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rifampicin (Option B):

Penetrates the CSF moderately, especially when meninges are inflamed, but less than isoniazid.

Pyrazinamide (Option C):

Good CSF penetration, but still slightly less than isoniazid, especially in non-inflamed meninges.

Streptomycin (Option D):

Poor CSF penetration; generally ineffective for CNS TB unless meninges are inflamed.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used as 'sterilizing' agent which is active against residual intracellular organisms that may cause relapse?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pyrazinamide is an important front-line drug used in conjunction with isoniazid and rifampin in short-course (i.e., 6-month) regimens as a “sterilizing” agent active against residual intracellularorganisms that may cause relapse.
  • Tubercle bacilli develop resistance to pyrazinamide fairly readily, but there is no cross-resistance with isoniazid or other antimycobacterial drugs.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Isoniazid (Option A):

Highly bactericidal against rapidly dividing mycobacteria, but less effective against dormant or slowly multiplying bacilli, so not the primary sterilizing agent.

Rifampicin (Option B):

Bactericidal and effective against intracellular bacteria, but pyrazinamide is considered more effective as a sterilizing agent in acidic environments.

Streptomycin (Option D):

Bactericidal aminoglycoside; primarily active against extracellular organisms, poor intracellular activity, and not considered a sterilizing agent.

questions.text: Type 1 & 2 lepra reaction treated with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Treatment of choice for type 1 as well as type 2 lepra reaction is corticosteroids.
  • For severe reaction, prednisolone 40-60mg/day is started immediately and continued till the reaction subsides.
  • The dose is then tapered over 2-3 months.
  • For resistant cases of Erythema nodosum leprosum drug of choice is thalidomide.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Dapsone (Option B):

Primary drug for multibacillary leprosy, but does not control the inflammatory reactions seen in type 1 or type 2 lepra reactions.

Minocycline (Option C):

Has antimicrobial activity against Mycobacterium leprae, but not indicated for acute lepra reactions.

Rifampicin (Option D):

Bactericidal against Mycobacterium leprae, part of MDT (multidrug therapy), but does not treat the immunologic reactions.

questions.text:
Which of the following drug given supervised as per national leprosy elimination programme?
i) Rifampicin 600 mg once a month
ii) Clofazimine 300 mg once a month
iii) Dapsone 100 mg daily
iv) Clofazimine 50 mg daily
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under NLEP

  • Rifampicin and Clofazimine are given under supervision for both Multibacillary and Paucibacillary Leprosy.
  • Rifampicin is given 600 mg once a month under supervision.
  • Clofazimine is given 300 mg once a month under supervision and 50 mg daily unsupervised for 28 days.
  • Dapsone is given 100 mg once daily unsupervised for 28 days.
  • Multibacillary Leprosy is treated for 12 months and Paucibacillary Leprosy for 6 months.

Under RNTCP, DOTS:

  • Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol are administered under supervision.

Explanation fo Incorrect Options:

Dapsone 100 mg daily (Option iii):

Taken daily by the patient at home, not under supervision.

Clofazimine 50 mg daily (Option iv):

Also taken daily at home, not part of the supervised monthly doses.

Option A (i, ii, iii, iv):

Incorrect because daily doses are not supervised; only monthly doses of rifampicin and clofazimine are supervised.

Option D (i only):

Incorrect because supervised monthly clofazimine is also included in the regimen.
